comments.html:
And this is why I love writing blog posts ;)) I always learn something new.

Reworded the blog post (although I still somewhat disagree on the "most" part of your statement).
comments.name: Ivan Pepelnjak

comments.html: Most firewall vendors support ADVPN these days so it's down to preference / budget ;)
comments.name: Anonymous

comments.html:
Hmmm... it might be worth considering whether it's their ignorance, or whether they have hidden assumptions that are not obvious from their question (like "having low-end router at remote end" or "having to run routing protocol over the VPN").

In any case, would you agree with my assertion that it's either one-or-few-vendor full-mesh VPN, or any-to-any-vendor P2P IPsec VPN?
comments.name: Ivan Pepelnjak

comments.html: Oh yeah, absolutely, I agree with that. No Checkpoint is ever going to do a meshed VPN with, say, a Fortinet. Unless you use ADVPN.
comments.name: Unknown

comments.html:
I sometimes have to smile when network engineers talk about firewalls :) I am a security engineer and all major enterprise firewalls have had meshed VPNs (e.g. direct spoke to spoke without the need to go through the hub) for many years, long before the terms DMVPN and ADVPN were even created ;)

Checkpoint, Juniper, Paloalto, Fortinet, you name it... they all had it for like... forever :)
comments.name: Unknown

comments.html: I'm not exactly a VPN person, but no, I don't.
comments.name: Ivan Pepelnjak

comments.html:
Thanks for posting this.

Do you see much traction with RFC6407 GDOIv2? In principle it interoperates statelessly between C & J...

https://www.juniper.net/documentation/en_US/junos/topics/concept/vpn-security-group-overview.html
comments.name: Blake
